{{Use British English|date=November 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Richard Robert Madden | image = Richard Robert Madden (United Irishman).jpg | image_size = | caption = Richard Robert Madden in 1858 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1798|8|22|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Dublin]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1886|2|5|1798|8|22|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Booterstown]] | death_cause = | other_names = | known_for = {{plainlist| * Doctor * Writer * Abolitionist * Historian of the [[United Irishmen]] }} | notable_works = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = [[Thomas More Madden]] (son) | nationality = [[Ireland|Irish]] }} '''Richard Robert Madden''' (22 August 1798 – 5 February 1886) was an Irish doctor, writer, [[Abolitionism in the United Kingdom|abolitionist]] and historian of the [[United Irishmen]]. Madden took an active role in trying to impose anti-slavery rules in [[Jamaica]] on behalf of the British government. ==Early life== [[File:(1829) MADDEN, Richard Robert in Syrian Costume.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Madden undercover in [[Syria]], exploring the Ottoman Empire]] Madden was born at [[Wormwood Gate]] Dublin on 22 August 1798 to Edward Madden, a silk manufacturer and his wife Elizabeth (born Corey) .{{cite odnb|title=Madden, Richard Robert (1798–1886)|first=Lynn|last=Milne|id=17753|accessedate=16 October 2015}} His father had married twice and fathered twenty-one children.[http://www.egypt-sudan-graffiti.be/Richard-Robert-Madden.htm Richard Robert Madden], egypt-sudan-graffiti.be, Retrieved 16 October 2015 Madden attended private schools and was found a medical apprenticeship in [[Athboy]], [[Co. Meath]]. He studied medicine in Paris, Italy, and St George's Hospital, London. While in [[Naples]] he became acquainted with [[Marguerite, Countess of Blessington|Lady Blessington]] and her circle. From 1824 to 1827 he was in the [[Levant]] as a journalist, and later published accounts of his travels. In 1828 Madden married Harriet Elmslie, daughter of John Elmslie (1739–1822) of Jamaica, a slave-owner. He then for five years practised medicine in [[Mayfair]], London.{{citation|url = https://www.ucl.ac.uk/lbs/person/view/2146641017|access-date = 17 February 2016|title = Legacies of British Slave-ownership}} ==Abolitionist in Jamaica== Madden became a recruit to the abolitionist cause. The [[slave trade]] had been illegal in the British Empire since 1807, but slavery still existed. The slave trade continued, and many not actively involved were complicit with it.{{cite journal|last1=Murray|first1=David.R.|title=Richard Robert Madden|date=1972|jstor=30088913}} From 1833, Madden was employed in the British civil service, first as a [[justice of the peace]] in Jamaica, where he was one of six Special Magistrates sent to oversee the eventual liberation of Jamaica's slave population, according to the terms of the [[Slavery Abolition Act 1833]]. From 1835 he was Superintendent of the freed Africans in [[Havana]]. In 1839 he became the investigating officer into the slave trade on the west coast of Africa, in 1847 the secretary for the [[Swan River Colony]]. He returned to Dublin and in 1850 he was named secretary of the Office for Loan Funds in Dublin.{{cite book|last=Boylan|first= Henry |year=1998|title=A Dictionary of Irish Biography, 3rd Edition|pages=262|location=Dublin|publisher=Gill and MacMillan|isbn=0-7171-2945-4}} ==Death== Madden died at his home in [[Booterstown]], just south of Dublin city, in 1886 and is interred in [[Donnybrook Cemetery]]. ==Published works== [[File:RRMADDEN.jpg|Madden at the [[World Anti-Slavery Convention|1840 Anti Slavery conference]]|thumb]] Besides several travel diaries (Travels in Turkey, Egypt etc. in 1824–27, 1829,[https://books.google.com/books?id=RVxjAAAAMAAJ Travels in Turkey, Egypt, Nubia and Palestine in 1824, 1825, 1826 & 1827 (online version)] and others (1833)), his works include the historically significant book ''The United Irishmen, their lives and times'' (1843, 7 Vols.),[https://books.google.com/books?id=nfEBAAAAMAAJ The United Irishmen, their lives and times (online version)] which contains important details on the causes of the [[Irish Rebellion of 1798]]. His other books include: * ''The Mussulman.'', London, H. Colburn and R. Bentley, 1830. 3 vol. {{LCCN|42044802}}. Available on Google Books: [https://books.google.com/books?id=WQYlAAAAMAAJ vol. 1], [https://books.google.com/books?id=igYlAAAAMAAJ vol. 2] and [https://books.google.com/books?id=zQYlAAAAMAAJ vol. 3]. * ''The infirmities of genius illustrated by referring the anomalies in the literary character to the habits and constitutional peculiarities of men of genius.'', London, Saunders and Otley, 1833. 2 vol. {{LCCN|15013521}}. Available on Google Books: [https://books.google.com/books?id=FL0ZAAAAIAAJ vol. 1] and [https://books.google.com/books?id=Pr0ZAAAAIAAJ vol. 2]. * ''A Twelvemonth’s Residence in the West Indies, during the transition from slavery to apprenticeship; with incidental notice of the state of society, prospects, and natural resources of Jamaica and other islands.'', Philadelphia, Carey, Lea and Blanchard, 1835. 2 vol. {{LCCN|02013566}}. Available on Google Books: [https://books.google.com/books?id=Os5zpXSrsY4C vol. 1] and [https://books.google.com/books?id=vUBCK0fHOAkC vol. 2]. ** New edition, under the same title: Westport, Connecticut, Negro Universities Press, 1970. {{ISBN|0-8371-3232-0}}. {{LCCN|70100309}} * Juan Francisco Manzano, ''Poems by a slave in the island of Cuba, recently liberated; translated from the Spanish, by R. R. Madden, M.D., with the history of the early life of the negro poet, written by himself; to which are prefixed two pieces descriptive of Cuban slavery and the slave-traffic, by R. R. M.'', London, T. Ward & Co., 1840. [9]-188 p. {{LCCN|01013046}} **Note that there is an ew edition, under a shorter title: ''The Life and Poems of a Cuban Slave : Juan Francisco Manzano, 1797–1854 / edited by Edward J. Mullen'', Hamden, Connecticut : Archon Books, 1981. vii, 237 p. {{ISBN|0-208-01900-6}}. {{LCCN|81003652}} – Madden's name as editor and translator seems to be given inside the book. * ''The Connexion between the Kingdom of Ireland and the Crown of England ... With an appendix of the Privy Council correspondence during ... 1811, 1812, 1816, 1817.'', Dublin : James Duffy, 1845. iii-340 p. * ''The History of the Penal Laws Enacted Against Roman Catholics'', London : Thomas Richardson and Son, 1847. 1 vol. (80 p.). Available on [https://books.google.com/books?id=E-wDAAAAQAAJ Google Books]. * ''The Life and Times of [[Robert Emmet]], Esq.'', Dublin : James Duffy Publisher, 1847 (first edition), XV-VII-343 p. ([https://books.google.com/books?id=N6YDAAAAYAAJ available on Google Books]. Second edition : Glasgow :Cameron, Ferguson & Co., 1902, 272 p. {{LCCN|04004402}}. * ''The island of Cuba: its resources, progress, and prospects, considered in relation especially to the influence of its prosperity on the interests of the British West India Colonies.'', London, C. Gilpin; [etc., etc.] 1849. xxiv-252 p. {{LCCN|29023832}} * ''The shrines and sepulchres of the Old and New World; records of pilgrimages in many lands and researches connected with the history of places remarkable for memorials of the dead, or monuments of a sacred character; including notices of the funeral customs of the principal nations, ancient and modern.'', London, T. C. Newby, 1851. 2 vol. {{LCCN|16020251}} * ''The Life and Martyrdom of [[Girolamo Savonarola|Savonarola]], illustrative of the history of church and state connexion.'', London, T. C. Newby, 1853. 2 vol. {{LCCN|06023658}}. Available on Google Books: [https://books.google.com/books?id=r_k-SVSrYpgC vol. 1] and [https://books.google.com/books?id=psxVSxM3OhkC vol. 2]. * ''The Literary Life and Correspondence of the [[Marguerite Gardiner, Countess of Blessington|Countess of Blessington]]'', London, T. C. Newby, 1855. 3 vol. {{LCCN|13007744}}. Available on Google Books: [https://books.google.com/books?id=nMVkAAAAMAAJ vol. 1], [https://books.google.com/books?id=0WAJAAAAQAAJ vol. 2] and [https://books.google.com/books?id=ev8ZAAAAYAAJ vol. 3]. ** New edition, under the same title: New York, AMS Press, 1973. 3 vol. {{ISBN|0-404-07720-X}}. * ''Phantasmata ; or, Illusions and fanaticisms of Protean forms, productive of great evils.'', London, T. C. Newby, 1857. 2 vol. {{LCCN|11006864}} * ''The Turkish Empire. In its Relations with Christianity and Civilization.'', London, T. C. Newby, 1862. 2 vol. {{LCCN|05009240}}. Available on Google Books: [https://books.google.com/books?id=eOxV30gVyK8C vol. 2]. * ''[[Galileo Galilei|Galileo]] and the [[Inquisition]]'', London: Burns & Lambert; Dublin: J. Mullany, 1863. vi-210 p. * ''Historical Notice of Penal Laws Against Roman Catholics: Their Operation and Relaxation During the Past Century, of Partial Measures of Relief in 1779, 1782, 1793, 1829, and of Penal Laws which Remain Unrepealed, Or Have Been Rendered More Stringent by the Latest So-called Emancipation Act.'', London : Thomas Richarson and Son, 1865. 241 p. Available on [https://books.google.com/books?id=kzslgsg69tcC Google Books]. * ''The history of Irish periodical literature, from the end of the 17th to the middle of the 19th century, its origin, progress, and results; with notices of remarkable persons connected with the press in Ireland during the past two centuries.'', London : T. C. Newby, 1867. 2 vol. (vii-338 p. + 531 p.). Available on Google Books: [https://books.google.com/books?id=G2QLAAAAYAAJ vol. 1] and [https://books.google.com/books?id=lZ84AAAAIAAJ vol. 2]. * ''The memoirs (chiefly autobiographical) from 1798 to 1886 of Richard Robert Madden. Edited by his son Thomas More Madden.'', London, Ward & Downey, 1891. 4-328 p., {{LCCN|40018630}} His time in Jamaica is also noticeable for his collection of letters and autobiographical accounts of several Muslim African slaves there at the time. These accounts are dealt with in his two-volume memoir, ''A Twelve Month's Residence in the West Indies''. He also wrote poetry for [[The Nation (Irish newspaper)|The Nation]].{{cite book|last=Lalor|first= Brian |year=2003|title=The Encyclopedia of Ireland|location=Yale|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-09442-8}} ==Family== Madden's wife was Harriet Elmslie (died 1888); they had three sons, among them [[Thomas More Madden]]. She was also the youngest of 21 children. Born in Marylebone in 1801 and baptised there into the Church of England,{{cite web|title = "England Births and Christenings, 1538-1975" , FamilySearch|url = https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:NYR6-7XS|access-date= 17 February 2016}} she was the child of John Elmslie (1739–1822), a Scot who owned hundreds of slaves on his plantations in Jamaica, and his wife Jane Wallace (1760 – 1801). Both Harriet's parents were of Quaker stock, but while living in Cuba she converted to Roman Catholicism.{{citation|url =http://www.egypt-sudan-graffiti.be/Richard-Robert-Madden.htm|access-date = 17 February 2016|title = Memorial in Donnybrook Cemetery}} == Bibliography == * Gera Burton, ''Ambivalence and the postcolonial subject : the strategic alliance of Juan Francisco Manzano and Richard Robert Madden'', New York : Peter Lang, 2004, xii-144 p., {{ISBN|0-8204-7058-9}}, {{LCCN|2003019581}} * Christopher Keniry, ''An Irish Doctor in the Caribbean, Richard Robert Madden's relationship with the island of Jamaica, Limerick : 2014, available from Mary Immaculate College Library.'' == References == {{commons category}} {{DNB poster|Madden, Richard Robert}} {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Madden, Richard Robert}} [[Category:British abolitionists]] [[Category:Irish civil servants]] [[Category:Irish writers]] [[Category:Irish historians]] [[Category:People from Dublin (city)]] [[Category:1798 births]] [[Category:1886 deaths]] [[Category:Civil servants in Ireland (1801–1922)]]

{{Nasrani people}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} '''Saint Thomas Christian music''' refers to the [[music]]al traditions of the [[Saint Thomas Christian]] community of [[Kerala]], [[India]]. It is chiefly [[liturgical music|liturgical]] and is derived from ancient [[Syriac Christian]] music from the [[Middle East]], with remarkably little influence from local Indian styles. Of particular significance is the prevalence of the [[organum]] singing style. As a result of the community's isolation and conservatism, these traditions may retain elements of the earliest forms of [[Early Christian music]].
==History== The [[Saint Thomas Christians]] trace their origins to the evangelical activity of [[Thomas the Apostle]] in the 1st century. The community grew under the influence of migration from Syrians, members of the [[Church of the East]]. The community's modern musical traditions may be derived from this connection.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Ross |first1= Israel J. |year= 1980 |title= Ritual and Music in South India: Syrian Christian Liturgical Music in Kerala |journal= Asian Music |volume= 11 |issue= 1 |pages= 83–85|publisher= University of Texas Press|jstor= 833968}}</ref> Into the 20th century, Saint Thomas Christian liturgy was performed and sung in the [[Syriac language]], though today this largely has been replaced with the local language, [[Malayalam]].<ref name=Ross85>{{cite journal |last1= Ross |first1= Israel J. |year= 1980 |title= Ritual and Music in South India: Syrian Christian Liturgical Music in Kerala |journal= Asian Music |volume= 11 |issue= 1 |page= 85|publisher= University of Texas Press|jstor= 833968}}</ref> Due to the community's resistance to outside influence and isolation, the music of the Saint Thomas Christians may preserve elements of the earliest forms of Christian music.<ref name=Ross80>{{cite journal |last1= Ross |first1= Israel J. |year= 1980 |title= Ritual and Music in South India: Syrian Christian Liturgical Music in Kerala |journal= Asian Music |volume= 11 |issue= 1 |page= 80 |publisher= University of Texas Press|jstor= 833968}}</ref>
Scholar Israel G. Ross compares Saint Thomas Christian music to that of the [[Jews]] in Kerala. [[Jewish music]] influenced the early Christian music ancestral to the Saint Thomas Christian forms, and Jews have lived in similar conditions to the Thomas Christians in [[Kerala]] for centuries.<ref name=Ross80/> As such, Christian and Jewish music and culture in Kerala feature many parallels and similarities.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Ross |first1= Israel J. |year= 1980 |title= Ritual and Music in South India: Syrian Christian Liturgical Music in Kerala |journal= Asian Music |volume= 11 |issue= 1 |pages= 80–81 |publisher= University of Texas Press|jstor= 833968}}</ref> For example, a Saint Thomas Christian blessing given by a dying father to his children is similar to the Jewish [[Amidah]].<ref name=Ross85>{{cite journal |last1= Ross |first1= Israel J. |year= 1980 |title= Ritual and Music in South India: Syrian Christian Liturgical Music in Kerala |journal= Asian Music |volume= 11 |issue= 1 |page= 82|publisher= University of Texas Press|jstor= 833968}}</ref> These similarities may reflect a common origin in the ancient Middle East.<ref name=Ross88>{{cite journal |last1= Ross |first1= Israel J. |year= 1980 |title= Ritual and Music in South India: Syrian Christian Liturgical Music in Kerala |journal= Asian Music |volume= 11 |issue= 1 |pages= 88 |publisher= University of Texas Press|jstor= 833968}}</ref>
{| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" align="center" width="40%" |- style="border: solid 1px" |- ! colspan="4" style="background:#fafad2;"|The Saint Thomas Christian father's blessing, as compared to the Jewish [[Amidah]] |- ! colspan="1" style="background:#fafad2;"| Saint Thomas Christian blessing ! colspan="1" style="background:#fafad2;"| [[Amidah]] |- | God gave his blessing to Abraham, Abraham gave that blessing to Isaac, Isaac gave that blessing to Jacob, Jacob ...to my forefathers, My forefathers...my parents, And my parents...to me, Now, dear son (daughter), I give that blessing to you. || Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, and God of our fathers, God of Abraham, God of Isaac, and God of Jacob, the great, mighty and revered God... |- ! colspan="4" style="background:#ffffe0;"| Ross 1979 |- |}
==Structure== Saint Thomas Christian music derives from archaic Syriac forms, with little discernible influence from [[Indian classical music]] or other local traditions.<ref name=Ross80/> [[Liturgical music]] is performed in two [[mode (music)|modes]]: ''kadmoyo'' and ''hamisoyo''. These are similar to the [[Arabic language|Arabic]] ''[[maqama]]t'' and may be derived from an ancient [[Syriac sacral music|Syriac system]] that existed in the Middle East in the early centuries of Christianity, and which may be related to the system known as [[oktoechos]].<ref name=Ross85/> Intonation is similar to the Syriac standard, featuring no [[augmented second]] or [[microtonal]] alteration characteristic of Indian music.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Ross |first1= Israel J. |year= 1980 |title= Ritual and Music in South India: Syrian Christian Liturgical Music in Kerala |journal= Asian Music |volume= 11 |issue= 1 |pages= 86 |publisher= University of Texas Press|jstor= 833968}}</ref>
The [[organum]] singing style is common in Saint Thomas Christian music. It appears in [[antiphons]], [[responsory|responsories]], and [[hymn]]s. Ross notes that this is found among three other disparate and isolated cultures: the nearby [[Cochin Jews]], the [[Yemenite Jews]], and the [[Samaritans]]. Organum may be sung in either duplum or triplum. In the former it is sung in the [[Perfect fifth|fifth]] when the boys and men sing together with the [[cantus firmus]] in the upper voice, or in the [[perfect fourth|fourth]] when the groups sing alone. In triplum it is sung in the fourth and octave.<ref name=Ross88/>
[[File:CommonOriginJewishandKeralaNasrani.JPG|Similarities in traditional liturgical music of Kerala Jews and Nasranis (Syrian Christians)]]
The [[Margam Kali]] is a traditional Saint Thomas Christian dance. The accompanying music is performed by a choir singing in Syriac chant, with a ''sleeyankolu'' ([[Triangle (musical instrument)|triangle]]) maintaining rhythm. Another traditional instrument is the [[violin]] or ''revekka''.<ref name= Choondal>Chummar Choondal (1983). "Christian folk songs". ''Kerala Folklore Academy'', p 56.</ref>
==Chant accentuation== Traditional chant accentuation derives from the Syriac standard, which was instituted by the scholars known as the [[Masoretes]] in the Middle Ages. The form is similar to that codified by the [[Hebrew]] [[Linguist|grammarians]] of [[Tiberias]] for Jewish cantillation of the Bible. It features dot notation above, below, and to the side of words in the text. The names of the notations are expressive, reflecting the style of Syriac Bible reading and chant in general.<ref name=Ross83>{{cite journal |last1= Ross |first1= Israel J. |year= 1980 |title= Ritual and Music in South India: Syrian Christian Liturgical Music in Kerala |journal= Asian Music |volume= 11 |issue= 1 |pages= 83|publisher= University of Texas Press|jstor= 833968}}</ref>
==Thoma Parvam== One important Saint Thomas Christian song is the "Thoma Parvam", or "Song of Thomas".<ref>{{cite book |title= Christianity in India: From Beginnings to the Present |last= Frykenberg |first= Eric |year= 2008 |publisher= Oxford University Press |isbn= 0-19-826377-5 |page= 92}}</ref> The song contains a [[colophon (publishing)|colophon]] claiming it was first written in 1601 by a certain Maliekel Thoma Ramban, though the manuscripts are of a much later date. The words give an account of [[Thomas the Apostle]]'s purported evangelical work in India in the 1st century.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Thoma |first1= P. J. |year= 1984 |title= The South Indian Tradition of the Apostle Thomas |journal= Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society |volume= 56 |issue= |pages= 83–85|publisher= |url= http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayFulltext?type=1&fid=5702828&jid=JRA&volumeId=56&issueId=S1&aid=5702820}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Commons category|Saint Thomas Christians}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox NRHP | name =Old Slater Mill | nrhp_type =nhl | image = Pawtucket slater mill.jpg | caption = | location= Roosevelt Avenue, [[Pawtucket, Rhode Island]] | coordinates = {{coord|41|52|39|N|71|22|57|W|display=inline,title}} | area = {{convert|4.23|acre|ha}}<ref name="nrhpinv2"/> | built =1793 | designated_nrhp_type= November 13, 1966<ref name="nhlsum">{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=6&ResourceType=District|title=Old Slater Mill|accessdate=June 29, 2008|work=National Historic Landmark summary listing|publisher=National Park Service|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007141543/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=6&ResourceType=District|archivedate=October 7, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> | added = November 13, 1966<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2007a}}</ref> | governing_body = Private | refnum=66000001 }}
The '''Slater Mill''' is a historic textile mill complex on the banks of the [[Blackstone River]] in [[Pawtucket, Rhode Island]], modeled after cotton spinning mills first established in England. It is the first water-powered cotton spinning mill in North America to utilize the Arkwright system of cotton spinning as developed by [[Richard Arkwright]].
[[Samuel Slater]], the mill's founder, apprenticed as a young man in [[Belper]], England with industrialist [[Jedediah Strutt]]. Shortly after immigrating to the United States, Slater was hired by [[Moses Brown (Providence)|Moses Brown]] of [[Providence, Rhode Island]] to produce a working set of machines necessary to spin cotton yarn using water power. Construction of the machines was completed in 1793, as well as a dam, waterway, waterwheel, and mill. Manufacturing was based on [[Richard Arkwright]]'s cotton spinning system, which included carding, drawing, and spinning machines. Slater initially hired children and families to work in his mill, establishing a pattern that was replicated throughout the [[Blackstone Valley]] and known as the "[[Rhode Island System]]". It was later eclipsed by [[Francis Cabot Lowell (businessman)|Francis Cabot Lowell]]'s [[Waltham System]].
Slater Mill was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] and designated a National Historic Landmark on November 13, 1966, the first property to be listed on the register.<ref name="nrhpinv2">Blanche Higgins Schroer (September 15, 1975) {{NHLS url|id=66000001|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory-Nomination: Old Slater Mill / Old Slater Mill; Slater Mill Historic Site}}, National Park Service and {{NHLS url|id=66000001|title=''Accompanying 6 images, including print from ca. 1812, drawing from 1907, and photos from 1973 and 1974 and undated''|photos=y}}</ref><ref name="nhlsum"/> In December 2014, the mill was added to the newly formed [[Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park]].
==Architectural history==
The original portion of the Slater Mill built in 1793 was six [[Bay (architecture)|bays]] long and two stories tall. Several additions were made beginning in 1801, and a second added in 1835. Between 1869 and 1872, a large addition was made to the north end of the mill. Cotton spinning continued until 1895, after which the mill was used for various industrial purposes until 1923. The building had suffered numerous fires in the past, and two fires occurred in 1912 which precipitated awareness of the building and the need for its preservation.
==From mill to museum== In 1921, the non-profit Old Slater Mill Association was founded with the purpose of saving the historic Mill. Efforts to restore the mill began in 1923; modern additions to the structure were removed, restoring the mill to its 1835 appearance. In 1955, it opened as a museum. Restoration of the nearby [[Wilkinson Mill]] (built 1810–1811) was completed in 1978 as part of the Slater Mill site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/master/pnp/habshaer/ri/ri0400/ri0471/supp/ri0471supp.pdf |title=Slater's Mill, supplemental information |last=Creer |first=Philip D. |date=April 10, 1942 |website=Historic American Buildings Survey |publisher=Library of Congress |location=Washington, D.C. |page=1 |accessdate=January 30, 2015}}</ref>
The Slater Mill site now serves as a museum, educational center, and music venue, which "celebrates innovation and the entrepreneurial spirit by engaging audiences in relevant cultural, historic, and artistic endeavors". It includes five acres of land on both sides of the Blackstone River, a dam on the river, two historic mills (the Slater Mill and Wilkinson Mill), and the Sylvanus Brown House (a house built in 1758 but moved to the site in the 1960s).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.slatermill.org/ |title=Slater Mill |accessdate=September 30, 2016}}</ref>
<gallery> Image:Slater Mill close.jpg|Slater Mill Image:Wilkinson Mill.jpg|Wilkinson Mill Image:Sylv Brown House Pawt.jpg|Sylvanus Brown House File:SlaterMill.JPG|View from Main Street Bridge </gallery>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox book | name = The Thirteenth Tribe | image = File:TheThirteenthTribe.jpg | caption = First UK edition | author = [[Arthur Koestler]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | subject = [[Khazars|Khazar Empire]] | publisher = [[Hutchinson (publisher)|Hutchinson]] | release_date = 1976 | media_type = Print | pages = 244 (1977 Pan Books edition) | isbn = 0-394-40284-7 | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Thirteenth Tribe''''' is a 1976 book by [[Arthur Koestler]], in which the author advances the thesis that [[Ashkenazi Jews]] are not descended from the historical [[Israelite]]s of antiquity, but from [[Khazars]], a [[Turkic peoples|Turkic people]]. Koestler hypothesized that the Khazars (who converted to [[Judaism]] in the 8th century) migrated westwards into Eastern Europe in the 12th and 13th centuries when the Khazar Empire was collapsing.
Koestler used previous works by [[Douglas Morton Dunlop]], [[Raphael Patai]] and Abraham Poliak as sources. His stated intent was to make [[antisemitism]] disappear by disproving its racial basis.
==Summary==
===Contents=== In the book, Koestler advances the thesis that [[Ashkenazi Jews]] are not descended from the historical [[Israelite]]s of antiquity, but from [[Khazars]], a [[Turkic peoples|Turkic people]] originating in and populating an empire north of and between the [[Black Sea]] and [[Caspian Sea]]. Koestler's hypothesis is that the Khazars – who converted to [[Judaism]] in the 8th century – migrated westwards into current Eastern Europe (primarily [[Ukraine]], Poland, [[Belarus]], [[Lithuania]], [[Hungary]] and Germany) in the 12th and 13th centuries when the Khazar Empire was collapsing.
At the end of the book's last chapter, Koestler summarizes its content and his intentions as follows: "In Part One of this book I have attempted to trace the history of the Khazar Empire based on the scant existing sources. In Part Two, Chapters V-VII, I have compiled the historical evidence which indicates that the bulk of Eastern Jewry — and hence of world Jewry — is of Khazar-Turkish, rather than Semitic, origin. In the last chapter I have tried to show that the evidence from anthropology concurs with history in refuting the popular belief in a Jewish race descended from the biblical tribe."
===Sources=== [[Mattias Gardell]] writes that Koestler's thesis is "partly based on amateur anthropology",<ref name=Gardell2003p124/> and its scientific arguments come from ''The Myth of a Jewish Race'' (1975) by [[Raphael Patai]] and his daughter Jennifer.<ref name=Bialep359>Biale, David. ''Blood and Belief: The Circulation of a Symbol Between Jews and Christians'', [[University of California Press]], 2008, {{ISBN|978-0-520-25798-6}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=1LQYpnV9GqIC&pg=PA259 p. 259.]</ref> It also relies on the work of earlier historians, particularly Russian-Israeli historian [[Abraham Poliak]]'s Hebrew book ''Khazaria: Toledot mamlakhah yehudit'' (1951),<ref name=Scammell2009p546/><ref name=Hundert2006p6>Hundert, Gershon David. ''Jews in Poland-Lithuania in the Eighteenth Century: A Genealogy of Modernity'', [[University of California Press]], 2006, {{ISBN|978-0-520-24994-3}}, p. 6 footnote 6.</ref> and the ''History of the Jewish Khazars'' (1954) by [[Douglas Morton Dunlop]], the author whom Koestler himself describes as a main source.<ref name=McInnes1999>McInnes, Neil. [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2751/is_1999_Fall/ai_56750595/pg_1 "Koestler and His Jewish Thesis"], ''[[The National Interest]]'', Fall 1999.</ref> Neil McInnes writes that Dunlop was, however, "much more tentative" in his conclusions, as were other historians of Khazars, including [[Peter Benjamin Golden|Peter Golden]] and Moses Shulvass.<ref name=McInnes1999/> Golden himself described the book as "controversial", stating it contained "sweeping claims of Khazar legacy and influence".<ref name=Golden2007p9>[[Peter Benjamin Golden|Golden, Peter B.]], "Khazar Studies: Achievements and Perspectives", in Golden, Peter B.; Ben-Shammai, Haggai; Róna-Tas, András. ''The World of Khazars: New Perspectives'', [[Brill Publishers]], 2007, {{ISBN|978-90-04-16042-2}}, p. 9.</ref>
===Koestler's reason for writing it=== Koestler biographer [[Michael Scammell]] writes that Koestler told French biologist Pierre Debray-Ritzen he "was convinced that if he could prove that the bulk of Eastern European Jews (the ancestors of today's Ashkenazim) were descended from the Khazars, the racial basis for anti-Semitism would be removed and anti-Semitism itself could disappear".<ref name=Scammell2009p546>[[Michael Scammell|Scammell, Michael]]. ''Koestler: The Literary and Political Odyssey of a Twentieth-Century Skeptic'', [[Random House]], 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-394-57630-5}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=bO7ANkFkH0UC&pg=PA546 p. 546.]</ref> According to [[George Urban]], Koestler's desire to connect Ashkenazi Jews with Khazars was "based on a tacit belief that the intellectual brilliance of and international influence of Hungarians and Jews, especially Hungarian Jews or Jewish-Hungarians, was due to some unexplained but clearly ancient affinity between the two peoples".<ref name=Urban1997p200>[[George Urban|Urban, George]]. ''Radio Free Europe and the Pursuit of Democracy'', [[Yale University Press]], 1997, {{ISBN|978-0-300-06921-1}}, p. 200.</ref>
==Reception== In ''[[The Invention of the Jewish People]]'', [[Shlomo Sand]], historian of cinema, French intellectual history, and nationalism at [[Tel Aviv University]], writes "while the Khazars scared off the Israeli historians, not one of whom has published a single paper on the subject, Koestler's ''Thirteenth Tribe'' annoyed and provoked angry responses. Hebrew readers had no access to the book itself for many years, learning about it only through the venomous denunciations".<ref>[[Shlomo Sand|Sand, Shlomo]]. ''The Invention of the Jewish People'', [[Verso Books]], 2009, p. 238.</ref> Writing in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education|Chronicle of Higher Education]]'' editor Evan Goldstein states "Sand suggests that those who attacked Koestler's book did so not because it lacked merit, but because the critics were cowards and ideologues. 'No one wants to go looking under stones when venomous scorpions might be lurking beneath them, waiting to attack the self-image of the existing ethnos and its territorial ambitions.'"<ref name=GoldsteinWSJ2009>Goldstein, Evan R. [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703746604574464023091024180 "Where Do Jews Come From?"], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', 29 October 2009.</ref>
In the Arab world the theory espoused in Koestler's book was adopted by persons who argued that if Ashkenazi Jews are primarily Khazar and not Semitic in origin, they would have no historical claim to Israel, nor would they be the subject of the [[Bible|Biblical]] promise of [[Canaan]] to the [[Israelite]]s, thus undermining the theological basis of both [[Religious Zionism|Jewish religious Zionists]] and [[Christian Zionism|Christian Zionists]].<ref>See: *[[Steven Plaut|Plaut, Steven]]. [http://www.jewishpress.com/pageroute.do/21499/ "The Khazar Myth and the New Anti-Semitism"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110325135452/http://www.jewishpress.com/pageroute.do/21499/ |date=25 March 2011 }}, ''[[The Jewish Press]]'', 9 May 2007. *Rossman, Vadim. ''Russian Intellectual Antisemitism in the Post-Communist Era'', [[University of Nebraska Press]], 2002, {{ISBN|978-0-8032-3948-7}}, p. 86.</ref> The Saudi Arabian delegate to the United Nations argued that Koestler's theory "negated Israel's right to exist".<ref name=Scammell2009p547>[[Michael Scammell|Scammell, Michael]]. ''Koestler: The Literary and Political Odyssey of a Twentieth-Century Skeptic'', [[Random House]], 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-394-57630-5}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=bO7ANkFkH0UC&pg=PA547 p. 547.]</ref> Koestler did not see alleged Khazar ancestry as diminishing the claim of Jews to Israel, which he felt was based on the United Nations mandate and not on Biblical covenants or genetic inheritance.<ref name=Gardell2003p124/><ref name = Barkun1994pp144-145>[[Michael Barkun|Barkun, Michael]]. ''Religion and the Racist Right: The Origins of the Christian Identity Movement'', [[University of North Carolina Press]], 1994, {{ISBN|978-0-8078-4638-4}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=bdGSbDaCQVsC&pg=PA145 pp. 144–145.]</ref> In his view, "[t]he problem of the Khazar infusion a thousand years ago... is irrelevant to modern Israel."<ref name = Barkun1994pp144-145/>
Koestler's book was praised by the neo-Nazi magazine ''The Thunderbolt'' as "the political bombshell of the century",<ref name=Scammell2009p547/> and it was enthusiastically supported by followers of the [[Christian Identity]] movement.<ref name=Gardell2003p124>[[Mattias Gardell|Gardell, Mattias]]. ''Gods of the Blood: The Pagan Revival and White Separatism'', [[Duke University Press]], 2003, {{ISBN|978-0-8223-3071-4}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=FIwwWSSL5JIC&pg=PA124 p. 124.]</ref><ref name=LewisPetersen2005p397>[[James R. Lewis (scholar)|Lewis, James R.]]; Petersen, Jesper Aagaard. ''Controversial New Religions'', [[Oxford University Press]], 2005, {{ISBN|978-0-19-515683-6}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=YCNd2YPFKTMC&pg=PA397 p. 397.]</ref> According to Jeffery Kaplan, ''The Thirteenth Tribe'' was "Identity's primary source for the Khazar theory"; they felt Koestler's book confirmed their own beliefs regarding Jews,<ref name = Barkun1994pp144-145/><ref name=Kaplan1997p48>Kaplan, Jeffrey. ''Radical Religion in America: Millenarian Movements from the Far Right to the Children of Noah'', [[Syracuse University Press]], 1997, {{ISBN|978-0-8156-0396-2}}, pp. 48, 191.</ref> and sold it "through their [[mail order]] services".<ref name = Barkun1994pp144-145/> Goldstein writes that "Koestler and the Khazar theory he advanced lives on in the fever swamps of the white nationalist movement".<ref name=GoldsteinTablet2009>Goldstein, Evan. [http://www.tabletmag.com/news-and-politics/18203/inventing-israel/ "Inventing Israel"], ''[[Tablet Magazine]]'', 13 October 2009.</ref> [[Michael Barkun]] writes that Koestler was apparently "either unaware of or oblivious to the use anti-Semites had made of the Khazar theory since its introduction at the turn of the century."<ref name = Barkun1994pp144-145/>
==Assessment== After it was first published, Fitzroy Maclean in ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'' called ''The Thirteenth Tribe'' excellent, writing "Mr. Koestler's book is as readable as it is thought-provoking. Nothing could be more stimulating than the skill, elegance and erudition with which he marshals his facts and develops his theories."<ref name=Maclean1976>Maclean, Fitzroy. [http://partners.nytimes.com/books/00/01/02/specials/koestler-tribe.html "Shalom Yisrah"], ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'', 29 August 1976, p. 219.</ref> Reviewing the work in the ''[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]'' in 1991, journalist and author Grace Halsell described it as a "carefully researched book" that "refutes the idea of a Jewish 'race'."<ref>Halsell, Grace. [http://www.wrmea.com/backissues/0591/9105071.htm "Book Reviews. The Thirteenth Tribe"], ''[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]'', May/June 1991, p. 71.</ref>
Despite some positive reviews in the press, James A. Beverley writes "When ''The Thirteenth Tribe'' was released, the academic critique of its research was prompt, public, and generally negative",<ref name=Beverley2009p342>Beverley, James A. ''Nelson's Illustrated Guide to Religions'', [[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]], 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-7852-4491-2}}, p. 342.</ref> and Evan Goldstein states that it was "savaged by critics".<ref name=GoldsteinWSJ2009/> An August 1976 review in [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]] described Koestler's theory as "all too facile, despite the obvious effort and time the author spent on his study", and stated that "Koestler offers a blizzard of information but not enough hard facts to support his thesis".<ref name=Time1976>Sheppard, R.Z. [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,945678-2,00.html#ixzz1JSmlUDc2 "Books: Caucasian Connection"], [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]], 23 August 1976.</ref> A November 1976 review in ''[[National Review]]'' stated that the work had "neither the value of a well-executed honest piece of scholarship nor the emotional appeal of a polemic – only the earmarks of a poorly researched and hastily written book".<ref name=Blumstock1986p94>Majeski, Jane. "Chutzpah: The Thirteenth Tribe, by Arthur Koestler", ''[[National Review]]'' '''27''', 12 November 1976, p. 1248, cited in Blumstock, Robert. "Going Home: Arthur Koestler's Thirteenth Tribe", ''Jewish Social Studies'' '''48''':2, 1986, p. 94.</ref> Koestler's analysis was described as a mixture of flawed etymologies and misinterpreted primary sources by Chimen Abramsky in 1976 and [[Hyam Maccoby]] in 1977.<ref>Abramsky, Chimen. "The Khazar Myth", ''Jewish Chronicle'', '''19''', 9 April 1976.</ref><ref>[[Hyam Maccoby|Maccoby, Hyam]]. "Koestler's Racism", ''Midstream'', '''23''', March 1977.</ref>
Barkun describes the book as an "eccentric work", and writes that Koestler was "unequipped with the specialist background the subject might be thought to require", but that he "nevertheless made an amateur's serious attempt to investigate and support the theory."<ref name = Barkun1994pp144-145/> Professor of [[History of the Jews in Poland|Polish-Jewish history]] [[Gershon D. Hundert]] wrote in 2006 "There is no evidence to support the theory that the ancestors of Polish Jewry were Jews who came from the Crimean Jewish kingdom of Khazaria", describing Koestler as the "best-known advocate" of the theory.<ref name=Hundert2006p6/> In 2009, [[Jeffrey Goldberg]] wrote that the book was "a combination of discredited and forgotten [ideas]".<ref name=GoldsteinTablet2009/>
Koestler biographers have also been critical of the work. In ''Arthur Koestler: The Homeless Mind'' (1998), [[David Cesarani]] states it makes "selective use of facts for a grossly polemical end" and is "risible as scholarship".<ref name=McInnes1999/> In ''Koestler: The Literary and Political Odyssey of a Twentieth-Century Skeptic'' (2009), [[Michael Scammell]] writes that Koestler's theory "was almost entirely hypothetical and based on the slenderest of circumstantial evidence",<ref name=Scammell2009p546/> and takes the book as evidence that Koestler's brain "was starting to fail him".<ref name=Scammell2009p548>[[Michael Scammell|Scammell, Michael]]. ''Koestler: The Literary and Political Odyssey of a Twentieth-Century Skeptic'', [[Random House]], 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-394-57630-5}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=bO7ANkFkH0UC&pg=PA548 p. 548.]</ref>
=== Genetic research === A 2005 study by Nebel ''et al.'', based on Y chromosome polymorphic markers, showed that [[Ashkenazi Jews]] are more closely related to other Jewish and Middle Eastern groups than to the populations among whom they lived in Europe. However, 11.5% of male Ashkenazim were found to belong to [[Haplogroup R1a]], the dominant Y chromosome haplogroup in Eastern Europeans, suggesting possible gene flow. Referencing ''The Thirteenth Tribe'', the study's authors note that "Some authors argue that after the fall of their kingdom in the second half of the 10th century CE, the Khazar converts were absorbed by the emerging Ashkenazi Jewish community in Eastern Europe." They conclude: "However, if the R-M17 chromosomes in Ashkenazi Jews do indeed represent the vestiges of the mysterious Khazars then, according to our data, this contribution was limited to either a single founder or a few closely related men, and does not exceed ~ 12% of the present-day Ashkenazim".<ref>Almut Nebel, Dvora Filon, Marina Faerman, Himla Soodyall and Ariella Oppenheim. [http://www.nature.com/ejhg/journal/v13/n3/full/5201319a.html "Y chromosome evidence for a founder effect in Ashkenazi Jews"], ''[[European Journal of Human Genetics]]'', (2005) 13, 388–391. {{doi|10.1038/sj.ejhg.5201319}} {{PMID|15523495}} (Published online 3 November 2004).</ref>
Writing in ''[[Science (magazine)|Science]]'', Michael Balter states Koestler's thesis "clash[es] with several recent studies suggesting that [[Jewishness]], including the Ashkenazi version, has deep genetic roots." He refers to a 2010 study by geneticist [[Harry Ostrer]] which found that Ashkenazi Jews "clustered more closely with Middle Eastern and Sephardic Jews, a finding the researchers say is inconsistent with the Khazar hypothesis" and concludes "that all three Jewish groups—Middle Eastern, Sephardic, and Ashkenazi—share genomewide genetic markers that distinguish them from other worldwide populations". Geneticist [[Noah Rosenberg]] asserts that although recent DNA studies "do not appear to support" the Khazar hypothesis, they do not "entirely eliminate it either."<ref>Balter, Michael. [http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2010/06/tracing-roots-jewishness "Tracing the Roots of Jewishness"], ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'', 3 June 2010.</ref>

'''Thomas Ebendorfer''' (August 10, 1388 – January 12, 1464) was an Austrian historian, professor, and statesman.
Born at [[Haselbach, Upper Austria|Haselbach]], in [[Upper Austria]], he studied at the [[University of Vienna]], where in 1412 he received the degree of [[Master of Arts]]. Until 1427 he was attached to the Faculty of Arts and lectured on [[Aristotle]] and [[Latin]] grammar. After 1419 he was also admitted to the theological faculty as 'cursor biblicus'. In 1427 he was made [[Licentiate (degree)|licentiate]] and in 1428 [[Master of Theology]]; soon after he became dean of the theological faculty, in which body he was a professor until his death.
He was rector of the University of Vienna in 1423, 1429, and 1445; and he was also canon of [[Stephansdom|St. Stephen's church]], and engaged in the apostolic ministry as preacher and as pastor of [[Perchtoldsdorf]] and of [[Falkenstein, Lower Austria|Falkenstein]] near Vienna.
He ranks high among the professors of the University of Vienna in the Fifteenth century. In the struggles which it had to sustain, he championed the rights and interests of the university with zeal and energy.
He represented the university at the [[Council of Basle]] (1432–1434), took an active part in all its discussions, and was one of the delegates sent by the council to [[Prague]] to confer with the [[Hussites]].
From 1440 to 1444 he was sent to various cities as ambassador of Emperor [[Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick III]]. He disapproved of the attitude of the [[Council of Basle]] towards both pope and emperor, and eventually withdrew from it.
His advocacy of the rights of the Vienna University, coupled with the attacks of his opponents, lost him the favour of the emperor, who saw in him a secret enemy.
In 1451 and 1452 he was in [[Italy]] and went to [[Rome]] where he obtained from the pope a confirmation of the privileges of the University of Vienna.
In the war between Frederick III and [[Albert of Brandenburg]] he tried to act as mediator but only fell into greater disfavour with Frederick.
His last years were clouded by the disturbances of the years 1461–1463 during which Austria had much to suffer from the [[King of Bohemia]], [[George of Podebrady]], and from internal conflicts.
==Historical and Religious Works== Ebendorfer is one of the most prominent chroniclers of the Fifteenth century. His "Chronicon Austriae" is a dull but frank and very detailed history of [[Austria]] to 1463. From 1400 on it is an indispensable source of Austrian history (ed. Pez in "Scriptores rerum Austriacarum", II, [[Leipzig]], 1725, 689-986; in this edition all of Book I and part of Book II were omitted).
His account of the [[Council of Basle]] appears in the "Diarium gestorum concilii Basileensis pro reductione Bohemorum" (ed. Birk in Monumenta concilii Basileensis, Scriptores, I, Vienna, 1875, 701-783).
He wrote also a history of the [[Roman emperor]]s, "Chronica regum Romanorum"; Books VI and VII, which are of independent value as sources, were edited by Pribram in the ''[[Mitteilungen des Instituts für österreichische Geschichtsforschung]]'', third supplementary volume ([[Innsbruck]], 1890-1894), 38-222.
Many of his writings are as yet unedited, among them commentaries on Biblical books, sermons, "Liber de schismatibus", "Liber Pontificum Romanorum" (see Levinson, "Thomas Ebendorfers Liber Pontificum" in "Mitteilungen des Instituts fur osterreichische Geschichtsforschung", XX, 1899, 69-99). 'Sermones Dominicales', printed in Strasbourg in 1478.

[[File:ZakharovPZ PtTGranovskogoGTG.jpg|right|thumb|Portrait of Timofey Granovsky by [[Pyotr Zakharov-Chechenets]], 1845]] '''Timofey Nikolayevich Granovsky''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|Тимофей Николаевич Грановский}}; 9 March 1813 – 4 October 1855) was a founder of [[mediaeval studies]] in the [[Russian Empire]].
Granovsky was born in [[Oryol]], Russia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adm.orel.ru/index.php?head=2&part=3&unit=52&in=6 |title=Oryol |accessdate=2009-10-15 |publisher=Government of Oryol Oblast' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315201200/http://www.adm.orel.ru/index.php?head=2 |archivedate=2010-03-15 |df= }}</ref> He studied at the universities of Moscow and Berlin, where he was profoundly influenced by [[Hegel]]ian ideas of [[Leopold von Ranke]] and [[Friedrich Karl von Savigny]]. He felt that the Western history was superior to that of his own country and became the first Russian to deliver courses on the medieval history of Western Europe (1839). Due to the strict censorship of the period, Granovsky assumed that lecturing provided a surer way of disseminating Western ideals in Russia than writing. His major printed work was his doctoral dissertation of 1849, ''Abbat Sugerii'' ([[Abbot Suger]]), in which he "portrayed the great abbot as the architect of royal centralization."<ref>Edward Alan Cole, "Timofei Nikolaevich Granovsky," ''Russian Literature in the Age of Pushkin and Gogol: Prose'' (Gale Research, 1999; {{ISBN|0787618535}}), p. 173.</ref> His master's thesis of 1845, "Volin, Yumsberg, i Vineta" ([[Wolin (town)|Wolin]], [[Jomsborg]], and [[Vineta]]), attempted to disprove the historicity of Vineta and was very controversial, offending the [[Slavophiles]].
His readings in the [[Moscow University]] were immensely popular and brought him in touch with other Westernizers. One of these, [[Alexander Herzen]], described Granovsky's lectures as "a draught of freedom in [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s Russia".
[[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]]'s novel ''[[The Possessed (novel)|The Possessed]]'' features a character, Stepan Trofimovich Verkhovensky, that is partly based on Granovsky. According to Cole, this "liberal who unwittingly inspired a generation of nihilists is unfair to Granovsky but is nevertheless another tribute to his importance as an inspiring teacher and a man of his age."<ref>Cole, "Timofei Nikolaevich Granovsky," p. 175.</ref>

{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Vasco Ferretti | image = Vasco Ferretti.jpg | caption = | birth_date = 25 August 1935 | birth_place = [[Buggiano]], [[Tuscany]], [[Italy]] | citizenship = [[Italy|Italian]] | nationality = [[Italy|Italian]] | occupation = Writer | genre = [[Historical Novel]] | movement = Post War Romance | notableworks = ''[[Kesselring]]'' (2009), ''Vip & Stars'' (1983), ''Le stragi naziste sotto la linea gotica. 1944: Sant'Anna di Stazzema, Padule di Fucecchio, Marzabotto''(2004), ''Dante Alighieri e la battaglia di Montecatini'' (2015) | website = {{URL|http://www.vascoferretti.it/}} }}
'''Vasco Ferretti''' (born 25 August 1935) is an Italian novelist, historian, professor and journalist from [[Buggiano]], [[Tuscany]]. He has written books in the fiction genres of [[historical novels]] and the [[Romance novel]]. His most important books are ''[[Kesselring]]'' (2009), ''Vip & Stars'' (1983), ''Dante Alighieri e la battaglia di Montecatini'' (2015), ''Le stragi naziste sotto la linea gotica 1944: Sant'Anna di Stazzema, Padule di Fucecchio, Marzabotto'' (2004).
==Biography== [[File:Montecatini Alto.jpg|thumb|left|Montecatini; where Ferretti lived most of his life, and where he currently lives with his wife.]] Vasco Ferretti was born in [[Buggiano]], [[Toscana]] (August 25, 1935). He was born in to a farming family, and obtained his master's degree in 1953, after studying for two years at the Catering College of [[Montecatini Terme|Montecatini]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ferretti|first1=Vasco|title=Kesselring|date=2009|publisher=Ugo Mursia Editore|location=Milano|url=http://www.ibs.it/code/9788842538189/ferretti-vasco/kesselring.html|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref> He then worked as a hotel doorman in [[Forte dei Marmi]]. In 1955–1956 he attended the annual course for trade union leaders of the Trade Union [[Italian Confederation of Workers' Trade Unions|CISL]] (Centro Studi di San Domenico di [[Fiesole]]), and emerged with a five-year assignment in [[Rome]] as the National Secretary of Tourism Workers in the same [[Italian Confederation of Workers' Trade Unions|CISL]]. He returned to Montecatini because of his family's economic problems and then studied to obtain a degree in [[philosophy]] and [[science of education]] in 1970 at the [[University of Urbino]], where he subsequently taught for two years. His victory at the Ministerial Competition allowed him to teach [[philosophy]] and [[history]] at the Institute of [[Pescia]] and [[Montecatini Terme|Montecatini]], until his retirement from teaching in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fuoco fatuo Il lato effimero dell amore|url=http://www.italybook.net/scaricare/fuoco-fatuo-il-lato-effimero-dell-amore-italian-edition|website=Italy Book|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> In 1975 he was listed in the Register of Journalists working in [[Tuscany]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Vasco Ferretti|url=http://www.giovaneholden.it/autori-a-z/autori-f/category/741-vasco-ferretti|website=Giovane Holden Edizioni|publisher=Giovane Holden Edizioni|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> For the past decades he has dedicated himself to [[historical research]] by publishing with Mursia (Milan) the following works: "Kesselring" (biography); "Nazi massacres of Marzabotto, Stazzema and marshes of Fucecchio."; "1944, a Red Blood Summer", set in Tuscany under the German occupation during [[World War II]]. Ferretti also works with other publishers: "Lager and Gulag" with Amazon (ebook on Kindle).
==Influences== Ferretti's works are highly influenced by traces of his philosophical and classical formation. In passages of his books there are multiple references to [[Franz Kafka]] in the syntax and in the paragraph structure.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vasco Ferretti|url=http://www.vascoferretti.it/|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref> His works are influenced by his association with [[Hermeticism]] and by his relationship with writers such as [[Giuseppe Ungaretti]], [[Salvatore Quasimodo]], [[Eugenio Montale]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Hermeticism|url=https://www.britannica.com/art/Hermeticism|website=Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=The Editors of Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> and [[Dante Alighieri]], who deeply influenced him and his literature. Hermeticism is a tradition which follows a set of philosophical and religious beliefs.
==Works==
===Kesselring (2009)===
''Kesselring'' (Edizioni Mursia, Milano, 2009) is a [[biography]] of [[Albert Kesselring]], a German [[Luftwaffe]] general, during [[World War II]]. The general was born on November 30, 1885, in Marktsteft (German empire) and died in a [[sanatorium]] in [[Bad Nauheim]] in West Germany, on 16 July 1960 at the age of 74, following a [[heart attack]].<ref>von Lingen, ''Soldat bis zum letzten Tag? Generalfeldmarschall Albert Kesselring'', p. 220</ref> He was one of the most skillful and highly decorated commanders of [[Nazi Germany]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Kesselring|url=http://www.vascoferretti.it/storiacontemporanea/kess-erling|website=Sezione Storia Contemporanea|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> The biography focuses on the general's military feats, his imprisonment and his participation to the [[Nuremberg trials]](1946)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Focardi|first1=Filippo|title=La questione dei processi ai criminali di guerra tedeschi in Italia: fra punizione frenata, insabbiamento di Stato, giustizia tardiva (1943-2005) Indice dell'articolo|journal=Annali dell'Istituto La Malfa|date=March 2006|url=http://storicamente.org/focardi_shoa}}</ref> as a witness, and to the trials in [[Venice]] (1947) as an accused. The structure of the biography is a historical-judiciary thriller, which is one of the characteristics that made this novel one of Vasco Ferretti's most relevant works.<ref>http://www.mursia.com/index.php/it/storia/kesselring-detail</ref> Author ''Ovidio Dallera'' in a review of ''Kesselring'' describes General [[Albert Kesselring|Kesselring]] as a character who earned his notoriety unlike many historical characters who have obtained an undeserved 'fame'.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Innocenti|first1=Marco|title=Libri / Kesselring|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/SoleOnLine4/Tempo%20libero%20e%20Cultura/2009/03/kesselring-libro.shtml?uuid=dd045fe4-10c1-11de-b369-ca847b73950d&DocRulesView=Libero&refresh_ce=1|accessdate=23 November 2016|publisher=Il Sole 24 Ore}}</ref> Vasco Ferretti, has been the first historical researcher that has brought the acts of the process against [[Albert Kesselring]] in [[Italy]], from the War Office in [[Kew]] ([[London]]), from which he also drew the book Vernichten.<ref>http://www.mursia.com/index.php/it/storia/storia-contemporanea/seconda-guerra-mondiale/nazismo/kesselring-detail</ref> ''Kesselring'' by Vasco Ferretti isn't the only book regarding the general, since other writings about him could also be found, for example: [[Kesselring]]'s own biography written by himself during his combat years, ''Albert Kesselring'' written by '''P. Paolo Battistelli''' <ref>{{cite web|title=Albert Kesselring|url=https://ospreypublishing.com/albert-kesselring|website=Osprey Publishing|accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> and ''Kesselring: the making of the Luftwaffe'' written by [[Kenneth Macksey]].
===Dante Alighieri e la battaglia di Montecatini (2015)===
''Dante Alighieri e la battaglia di Montecatini'' (EDIFIR, 2015) is a [[historical novel]] about the [[Battle of Montecatini]], on August 29, 1325 in the [[Province of Pistoia]]. The battle was fought in the [[Val di Nievole]] by the [[Republic of Pisa]], and the forces of both the [[Kingdom of Naples]] and the [[Republic of Florence]].{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} The [[Guelphs]] and the '''[[Capetian dynasty|Capetian]] House of Anjou''' hoped the battle represented the showdown for the [[Ghibellines]] of [[Pisa]] and of [[Lucca]], led by [[Uguccione della Faggiuola]] and [[Castruccio Castracani]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meek|first1=Christine E.|title=DELLA FAGGIUOLA, Uguccione|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/uguccione-della-faggiuola_(Dizionario-Biografico)/|website=Treccani|publisher=treccani.it|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref> but it turned out to be a tragic defeat to the detriment of [[Florence]] instead. [[Niccolò Machiavelli]], in his biography of Castruccio Castracani,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Antelminelli|first1=Coreglia|title=Vita di Castruccio Castracani: tiranno magnanimo e crudele|url=http://www.loschermo.it/46478/|website=loSchermo|publisher=loSchermo|accessdate=27 November 2016}}</ref> wrote that the battle only caused thousands of deaths.<ref>{{cite web|title=Battaglia montecatini2 dep|url=https://issuu.com/13460/docs/battaglia_montecatini2_dep|website=issuu|publisher=Comune di Pisa|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref> Due to the ransom of many prisoners, Florence suffered an economic collapse and this situation made complex the conditions of [[Dante Alighieri]], who was returning after thirteen years of exile. Dante himself, as well as all his biographers, desired to go back to Florence to spend the rest of his life.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dante Alighieri e la battaglia di Montecatini. 29 agosto 1315|url=http://www.unilibro.it/libro/ferretti-vasco/dante-alighieri-battaglia-montecatini-29-agosto-1315/9788879707657|website=Unilibro|publisher=Edifir|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref> It unfortunately was a life expectancy never assuaged.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dante Alighieri e la battaglia di Montecatini. 29 agosto 1315|url=https://www.ibs.it/dante-alighieri-battaglia-di-montecatini-libro-vasco-ferretti/e/9788879707657|website=Internet Bookshop Italia|publisher=EDIFIR|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref>
===Vernichten (1988)=== Vernichten (in German = 'annihilate') refers to the order given to the soldiers of the [[Wehrmacht]] for the massacre of the Marsh of Fucecchio in August 23–24, 1944. It was run by General Peter Eduard Crasemann and caused 174 victims (men, women and children).<ref>http://www.vascoferretti.it/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=39&catid=13&Itemid=243</ref> The massacre took place in the area between [[Pistoia]] and [[Florence]] that is called Marsh of [[Fucecchio]]. The reasons for the massacre are unclear, but could be related to false intelligence which pointed out the presence of gangs of [[Italian resistance movement|partisans]] in the Marsh of [[Fucecchio]].
===Le stragi naziste sotto la linea gotica. 1944: Sant'Anna di Stazzema, Padule di Fucecchio, Marzabotto=== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101III-Cantzler-042-16, Max Simon.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Max Simon]] {{see also|Sant'Anna di Stazzema massacre|Marzabotto massacre|}}
''Le stragi naziste sotto la linea gotica. 1944: Sant'Anna di Stazzema, Padule di Fucecchio, Marzabotto'' is an enquire book about the massacres committed by the [[Schutzstaffel|16. SS-Panzergrenadier-Division "Reichsführer SS"]] and the [[Panzer Division|26 Panzer division]] commanded by the [[Max Simon|Corps Commander Max Simon]].<ref>{{cite web|title=1944 – Settembre 29.30 – Strage di Marzabotto|url=http://www.anpireggioemilia.it/agenda-della-resistenza/1944-strage-di-marzabotto/|website=A.n.p.i. Reggio Emilia|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref> The book, released in 2004 analyzes the terroristic operations,<ref>(it) La Gazzetta della Spezia, ''[http://www.gazzettadellaspezia.it/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=26045:strage-di-sant-anna,-riaperte-le-indagini-per-il-tribunale-spezzino-fu-puro-terrorismo&Itemid=304 Strage di Sant'Anna, riaperte le indagini. Per il tribunale spezzino fu puro terrorismo]''</ref> committed by the nazi in order to intimidate and scare the population of [[Marzabotto]], [[Sant'Anna di Stazzema]] and Padule di Fucecchio.<ref>{{cite web|title=Le stragi naziste sotto la linea gotica. 1944|url=http://www.comune.monsummano-terme.pt.it/news/stragi-naziste-sotto-linea-gotica-1944-sant-anna-di-stazzema-padule-di-fucecchio-marzabotto|website=Comune di Monsummano|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref> The author provides a precise chronicle of the massacres and how they happened. The book also explores the background of those communities before the tragedy and the psychological impact these slaughters had on the population and on the [[Italian resistance movement|partisan resistance]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=McMahon|first1=Barbara|title=10 former Nazis convicted of Tuscan massacre|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/jun/23/secondworldwar.italy|accessdate=28 November 2016|agency=Online|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> Due to its relevant historical content for the Italian culture, the book was inserted into the historical series of the Italian editor Mursia<ref>{{cite web|title=Ferretti V.: Le stragi naziste sotto la linea gotica|url=http://www.mursia.com/index.php/it/storia/le-stragi-naziste-sotto-la-linea-gotica-detail|website=UGO MURSIA EDITORE|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref>
===Processo a Moravia (1994)=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:MoraviaIT.jpg|120px|thumb|left|Alberto Moravia]] --> In a late evening of September 1974 (16 years before his death), [[Alberto Moravia]] is the great defendant in a process that takes place in one of the "liberty" rooms of the Tamerici baths in [[Montecatini Terme|Montecatini]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Il Liberty a Montecatini Terme|url=http://www.oltrepistoia.it/scoprire-il-territorio/pistoia/borghi-e-paesi/valdinievole/145-il-liberty-a-montecatini-terme.html|website=Oltre Pistoia - Andare oltre per vedere altro|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Processo a Moravia|url=http://www.vascoferretti.it/criticaletteraria/processo-a-moravia|website=Vasco Ferretti- Autore - Home|accessdate=4 December 2016}}</ref> The accuser is [[Aldo Rossi]], the defender of Moravia is Geno Pampaloni, a well known Italian book reviewer. It was more a great opportunity for Moravia to express himself, his ideas and his motives to write rather than the focus on the process itself. He explained so much that it could have been possible to draft his autobiography. He was brought to the process because of his lack of proper interest in the country's affairs. He confesses his thoughts in front of an audience that previously had witnessed at the process of [[Pier Paolo Pasolini]] and accept his reasons as well as it did with Moravia's in this trial fiction. Moravia claims he is a disciple of Fëdor Dostoevskij ([[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]]): indeed traces of the Russian writer can be recognized in his literature.<ref>{{cite web|title=I gusti letterari di Alberto Moravia|url=http://www.letteratura.rai.it/articoli/i-gusti-letterari-di-alberto-moravia/998/default.aspx|website=Rai Cultura Letteratura|accessdate=4 December 2016}}</ref> [[Alberto Moravia]] outlines his strong tendency to tell stories and his great curiosity as to illustrate his disengaged literature. Geno Pampaloni deems him to be the most illustrious journalist in Italy; nowadays he is still remembered as one of the greatest journalist.<ref>{{cite web|title=Quando il giornalismo in Italia lo faceva Moravia|url=https://www.loccidentale.it/articoli/9642/quando-il-giornalismo-in-italia-lo-faceva-moravia|website=l'Occidentale-Orientamento quotidiano|accessdate=4 December 2016}}</ref>
===Vips e Stars, cento personaggi alle terme di Montecatini (1983)===
Vips and stars is a unique story of characters that recalls the [[Belle Époque]] period and the roaring '60s. Its main characters are divas, geniuses, kings, lords, queens, maraharaja, writers, politicians, musicians, movie producers, actors and actresses. These celebrities are inserted in the scenario of the faboulous and famous city of [[Montecatini Terme]].<ref>{{cite web|title=VIPS E STARS|url=http://www.vascoferretti.it/ricerchedistorialocale/vips-e-stars|website=Vasco Ferretti - Ricerche di storia locale|accessdate=4 December 2016}}</ref> The main personalities in this story are:
'''Characters''': '''Divas and Lords'''
* ''[[Lina Cavalieri]], diva of the [[Belle Epoque]]'' [[File:Lina Cavalieri 001.jpg|180px|thumb|right|Lina Cavalieri]] * ''[[Mary Pickford]] and [[Douglas Fairbanks]], ambassadors from [[Hollywood]]'' * ''[[Orson Welles]], the magnificent'' * ''[[William Holden]], the last king of [[Hollywood]]''
'''Politicians'''
* ''[[Enrico De Nicola]], gentleman president'' * ''[[Pietro Nenni]], father of the [[Socialism]]'' * ''[[Sandro Pertini]], the most beloved president''
'''Writers'''
* ''[[Massimo D’Azeglio]], the wounded at the Locanda Maggiore'' * ''[[Anita Loos]], the great muse of [[Hollywood]]''
'''Geniuses and Artists'''
* ''[[Giuseppe Verdi]], the genius and the VIP'' * ''[[Guglielmo Marconi]], father of the modern era'' * ''[[Giorgio De Chirico]], the immortal metaphysical'' * ''[[René Magritte]], at the start of the [[Surrealism]]''
'''Musicians'''
* ''[[Arrigo Boito]], Verdi and the [[Othello]]'' * ''[[Pietro Mascagni]], the "rusticano"'' * ''[[Giacomo Puccini]], a Boheme life'' * ''[[Richard Strauss]], Salome and the Rose cavalier'' * ''[[Herbert Von Karajan]], the [[Salzburg]] king''
===Fuoco fatuo. Il lato effimero dell'amore (2014)=== [[File:Fortedeimarmi04.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Night view of Forte Dei Marmi where most of the book is settled]] This romance, set in the 60's, is about the story of Alessandro and Denise, two young high school students that meet on the dance floor of a disco in the city of [[Pistoia]]. The two immediately fall in love passionately with each other but their passion will make them face the consequences of belonging to different social classes and their different aspirations. As the boy moves to [[Forte dei Marmi]] to seek work as a concierge in a luxury hotel, Denise, a rebel soul, decides to escape from the upper class society in order to pursue her desire of success without letting him know about her movements.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fuoco fatuo Il lato effimero dell amore|url=http://www.italybook.net/scaricare/fuoco-fatuo-il-lato-effimero-dell-amore-italian-edition|website=Italy Books|publisher=Italy Books|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> After all Alessandro doesn't give up and keeps following his love dream, facing rich entrepreneurs, actresses and movie directors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fuoco fatuo. Il lato effimero dell'amore|url=https://www.ibs.it/fuoco-fatuo-lato-effimero-dell-libro-vasco-ferretti/e/9788863965605#|website=Internet Bookshop Italia|accessdate=4 December 2016}}</ref> Ferretti shows in this work a snapshot of a period and of the generation of the time. The story is animated by a deep search of the meaning of life and by the never ending search under the surface of existence to get to its most authentic meaning<ref>{{cite web|title=Fuoco fatuo. Il lato effimero dell'amore|url=https://books.google.it/books/about/Fuoco_fatuo_Il_lato_effimero_dell_amore.html?id=bzvzrQEACAAJ&redir_esc=y|website=Google Books|publisher=Google|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref>
